revised_title: Chemical and Physiological Experiments on Living Cinchona Bark
tldr: The author investigates the presence and distribution of alkaloids in various parts of the cinchona plant, focusing on quinine, cinchonidine, and cinchonine. They find that the bark is the primary source of these alkaloids, with the trunk bark being the richest. The leaves and other parts of the plant contain minimal amounts of alkaloids, making them unsuitable sources for extraction.
